gen.metadata.title: BIRDS-1 CubeSat Constellation Using Compact UHF Patch Antenna
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and test a compact UHF band patch antenna for the BIRDS-1 CubeSat constellation (p. 6)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Integrate and test the antenna with the 1U BIRDS-1 satellite (p. 1); Ensure the antenna is lightweight and mechanically robust (p. 1); Achieve a compact size, low profile, and geometric characteristics (p. 6); Achieve a compact antenna dimension suitable for 1U CubeSat (p. 1); Integrate and test the antenna with the BIRDS-1 satellite body (p. 6); Not mentioned; Ensure good impedance matching and radiation pattern (p. 6)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna in different environmental conditions (p. 1); Explore the use of the UHF antenna in other small satellite applications (p. 11); Not mentioned; Explore further miniaturization techniques for UHF patch antennas (p. 1); Investigate the performance of the UHF antenna in different orbital environments (p. 11)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the UHF antenna into future CubeSat missions (p. 11); Perform additional environmental tests to ensure long-term reliability (p. 11); Integrate the antenna with other CubeSat components to ensure compatibility (p. 1); Not mentioned; Use the proposed antenna design for future 1U CubeSat missions (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a compact and efficient UHF patch antenna for 1U CubeSats due to the limited surface area and the need for reliable communication (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a compact UHF band patch antenna be designed for 1U CubeSat missions? (p. 6); How can a compact UHF patch antenna be designed to fit within the limited space of a 1U CubeSat? (p. 1); What are the performance characteristics of the proposed UHF patch antenna? (p. 1); Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics of the proposed UHF antenna compared to existing designs? (p. 6)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Agilent N5227A PNA microwave network analyzer (p. 5)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite element method (FEM) and Method of Momentum (MoM) (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of size, gain, and radiation pattern (p. 6)
esp.domain_results.gain: 0.55 dB realized gain, 1.01 dB peak gain (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Folded meander line patch, shorting pin, and partial ground plane with coaxial probe fed (p. 6)

gen.metadata.title: Microstrip Antenna with Slotted Rectangular Truncated Corner Patch for ADS-B Receiver on Cubesat
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and evaluate a microstrip antenna with a slotted rectangular truncated corner patch for ADS-B signal reception on a CubeSat (p. 2)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a gain of 4.22 dBi (p. 264); Evaluate the performance of the designed antenna through simulation and measurement (p. 2); Achieve a frequency range of 1084.6 - 1099.5 MHz (p. 264); Design an antenna that meets the required specifications for ADS-B signal reception (p. 2); Improve the axial ratio to 2.89 dB (p. 264)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna in different orbital conditions (p. 6); Further optimization of the antenna design (p. 264)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the designed antenna into CubeSat missions for ADS-B signal reception (p. 6); Use the designed antenna for ADS-B receivers in Cubesats (p. 264)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Ground-based ADS-B signal receivers have limited coverage areas, especially in areas difficult to reach by terrestrial communication. Satellite-based ADS-B signal reception technology is needed to expand the signal reception coverage area (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the gain and axial ratio of the microstrip antenna be improved? (p. 264); How can a microstrip antenna with a slotted rectangular truncated corner patch improve the performance of ADS-B signal reception on a CubeSat? (p. 2); What is the impact of the truncated corner method on the antenna's performance? (p. 264)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 264)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Improvement in gain by 3.2 dB compared to previous research (p. 264)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Microstrip antenna with slotted rectangular truncated corner patch (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: Design and Analysis of Circular-Polarized Patch Antenna at S-band for a Nanosatellite
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a circularly polarized patch antenna suitable for installation on a nanosatellite, with specific requirements for size, frequency band, and performance (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve matching properties with S11 below -6 dB (p. 3); Ensure circular polarization in the S-band (2.40–2.45 GHz) (p. 1); Fit the antenna within a 10 × 10 cm² ground platform (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further improvements in axial ratio in the operating frequency range (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a compact, lightweight, and efficient circularly polarized patch antenna for nanosatellites operating in the S-band (2–4 GHz) (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a circularly polarized patch antenna be designed to fit the dimensions and performance requirements of a nanosatellite? (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_dim: Diameter of the circular patch element: 57 mm (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Feed point moved 11 mm toward the edge of the antenna (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: Optimized Design and Multiphysics Analysis of a Ka-Band Stacked Antenna for CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a Ka-band stacked patch antenna for CubeSat applications, and to analyze its thermal and mechanical performance (p. 4)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Perform a multiphysics thermal and mechanical analysis to ensure operational stability (p. 1); Optimize the antenna geometry using a PSO algorithm (p. 8); Achieve a wideband operation and high gain (p. 1); Optimize the antenna design using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to achieve maximum bandwidth and return loss (p. 4); Conduct thermal and mechanical analysis to ensure the antenna can withstand the environmental conditions of a LEO mission (p. 7); Perform thermal and mechanical analysis of the antenna in a LEO environment (p. 8); Not mentioned; Evaluate the antenna performance in terms of bandwidth, gain, and radiation pattern (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore the use of other materials and configurations for further optimization (p. 1); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different orbital environments (p. 1); Investigate the use of other epoxy resins capable of reaching high tensile, shear, and flexural stresses (p. 12); Not mentioned; Explore the optimization of other antenna types for CubeSat applications (p. 8); Investigate the impact of different orbits and mission profiles on antenna performance (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the optimized design for future CubeSat missions (p. 1); Use mechanically performing resins or adaptive temperature control strategies to manage thermal and mechanical stresses (p. 12); Conduct further thermal and mechanical testing to validate the simulation results (p. 8); Not mentioned; Implement the optimized antenna design in CubeSat missions (p. 8); Perform similar multiphysics analyses for other CubeSat components (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need to optimize the design of a Ka-band stacked patch antenna for CubeSat applications, considering the unique environmental and thermal conditions of space (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a Ka-band stacked patch antenna be designed to meet the multiphysics constraints of CubeSat missions? (p. 1); How can a stacked patch antenna be optimized for CubeSat applications in the Ka-band? (p. 8); What are the thermal and mechanical performance characteristics of the optimized antenna in a LEO environment? (p. 8); How can the antenna design be optimized to meet the operational requirements in Ka-band for CubeSat applications? (p. 4); Not mentioned; What is the impact of thermal and mechanical stresses on the performance of the antenna? (p. 1); What are the thermal and mechanical stresses that the antenna will experience in a LEO mission, and how can they be mitigated? (p. 7)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm, finite difference time domain (FDTD) simulations, and heat transfer analysis (pp. 4-7)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in bandwidth and gain (p. 10)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Broadside radiation with stable gain over frequency (p. 10)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT/duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.001, h = 0.254 mm) (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Single feed point centered on an axis and shifted towards the orthogonal edge (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: Ka-band (26–34.7 GHz for down- and uplink) (p. 1)

gen.metadata.title: High-Gain Circular Polarized Microstrip Patch Array for X-band CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a high gain, left-hand circularly polarized (LHCP) microstrip patch antenna array for X-band CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design and optimize a single element CP patch antenna (p. 2); Develop a 36-element antenna array based on the optimized CP patch element (p. 3); Evaluate the performance of the array with and without the CubeSat body (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Conduct experimental validation of the proposed antenna array (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the proposed antenna array in CubeSat designs for high-data rate downlink communications (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Low data rate capabilities of CubeSats and the need for high gain, circularly polarized antennas to ensure reliable up/downlink communication (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can high gain, circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna arrays be designed for X-band CubeSat applications? (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: 90% of a 1U CubeSat's bottom face (100 × 100 mm²) (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: High-gain circularly polarized microstrip patch array (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: CP single-feed square patch with truncated corners (p. 2)
L = 6 mm, SL = 1.68 mm, SW = 1.79 mm, Px = 1.6 mm, Py = 0.48 mm (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: Design of S-band CubeSat Antenna
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design an S-band patch antenna with circular polarization suitable for CubeSat communication systems (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a resonance frequency of 2.4 GHz-2.45 GHz (p. 2); Achieve a bandwidth of 50 MHz (p. 2); Achieve a directional radiation pattern with a main lobe of 70 degrees (p. 2); Ensure a return loss better than 10 dBi and an antenna gain more than 0 dBi at 0 degrees (p. 2)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the antenna's performance under different environmental conditions (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further testing and validation of the antenna design in real-world CubeSat applications (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a compact, high-gain, circularly polarized S-band patch antenna for CubeSat communication systems (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a patch antenna be designed to achieve circular polarization and high gain for CubeSat applications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Directional with a main lobe of 73.7 degrees and a side lobe of -22.1 dBi (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Single-feed patch antenna with truncated corners (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: S-band Planar Antennas for a CubeSat
gen.objectives.main_objective: To compare the performance of shorted patch and CPW-feed square slot antennas for CubeSat communications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Evaluate the return loss, bandwidth, and gain of both antennas with and without the CubeSat body (p. 1); Re-dimension both antennas to operate at 2.45 GHz and compare their performance (p. 1); Not mentioned
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Apply further gain enhancement and size miniaturization techniques (p. 7); Not mentioned
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Use the re-dimensioned shorted patch antenna for CubeSat communications (p. 8)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Limited understanding of the performance of shorted patch and CPW-feed square slot antennas for CubeSat communications (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: Not mentioned; What are the effects of re-dimensioning these antennas to operate at 2.45 GHz? (p. 1); How do the shorted patch and CPW-feed square slot antennas perform with and without the CubeSat body? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite element method (FEM) based High Frequency Structure Simulator (HFSS) (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: Shorted patch: 900 MHz, CPW-feed square slot: 550 MHz (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Shorted patch antenna outperforms CPW-feed square slot antenna in terms of gain and bandwidth (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.gain: Shorted patch: 5.3 dB, CPW-feed square slot: 2.52 dB (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: Shorted patch: -27.5 dB, CPW-feed square slot: -27.5 dB (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.return_loss_bandwidth: Shorted patch: 900 MHz, CPW-feed square slot: 550 MHz (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_dim: Shorted patch: 83 × 83 mm², CPW-feed square slot: 75 × 75 mm² (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Shorted patch and CPW-feed square slot antennas (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Shorted patch: probe feed, CPW-feed square slot: coplanar waveguide (CPW) feed (p. 2)
Shorted patch: 18×15 mm² upper patch, 7.5×6.5 mm² lower patch, CPW-feed square slot: 4.2 mm width, 0.3 mm gap (p. 2)
